text: Such a great reading, thanks for sharing Vivek! Reminds me of this amazing talk from Emily Levine, and one of her quotes that stuck with me: "the trickster has the ability to hold his ideas lightly so that he can let room in for new ideas or to see the contradictions or the hidden problems with his ideas" <https://www.ted.com/talks/emily_levine_a_theory_of_everything>
There's a whole lot more in the video, and her jokes are hilarious :smile:  comedians are such great artists, and can really be powerful agents of change

As an author as well as an art lover, I must say I am very far from James Baldwin’s view as expressed in these lines. 

Human Art is a P2P affair. Understanding “The Artist” as someone different from those who are not creators of Art is a self-conscious way to set a distance between some inspired “divine” human beings and “the people”, “they”, who are thereArtists took the place of God in the XIXth century and the consequences are obvious in the XXth. The distance became so large that “the people” disconnected from “the artist” and turned to popular culture providers instead, and these became “the artists”. 

Any artist, who has developed the skills and has trained to express his/her unique human experience, is providing any human being who approaches his art work (a piece of music, a writing, an image...) the means for direct human communication. For me, Art is excellence in human communication, and the best art pieces are timeless because they are genuinely human and can connect human experiences through times and societies. Societies for art are just the context, some background... For an author like me the audience, the public, is just the sum of individuals. I always think of individual human beings, because “societies” doesn’t feel, suffer neither enjoy... and “society” is a socio-economic concept which is constantly used and abused. I don’t expect any society to take any purposeful action. Let’s better talk about Humanity as the sum of individual unique human beings. 

Whenever I find a text, a piece of music, or other art piece that I feel close to I am grateful to it’s author, the writer, musician, performer or whatever. Artists as such offer everyone of us their very refined senses to reveal out own common humanity, and doing so they help us open our eyes, ears, minds and heart providing the opportunity of connecting with ourselves better (a lifetime adventure). They are necessary and will always be as long as humans don’t give up on their unique humanity. I am glad that the Internet of Value can provide the ways for them to be rewarded for their invaluable work. 

As you can imagine I am not interested in Art neither in technology a means for shaping societies and serving political ideas. I think both can be beyond politics and I wish for them to be at the service of Humanity.

I must admit that when I see the term 'artist', the visuals in my head are the popular culture ones! I do agree with James Baldwin's take on artists being the ones who challenge the norm. My take on the passage is his definition of artist is someone who sees reality differently than other people, and because of that society pushes back

Yes, creative processes are surely different for popular artists than for “professionally trained ones”, like the classical musicians I have been had the luck to work with for more than 20 years. For them Art is all about genuine expression though highly demanding performances, art pieces... As far as I know, artists try to express that side of our humanity often hidden inside most of us. They don’t see reality differently, they just take the time to observe and analyze it, and they dig into deep emotions and feelings, and they reveal our common sufferings and pleasures.
Art is an invitation to reconnect with yourself. This is the reason art is so therapeutical, but for many this can also open some Pandora’s boxes, and thus invoke rejection. Art is actually powerful, and it has been used for good and for bad. In history. In the XXth century “societies” have been tamed by Art and Music used as propaganda (Hitler and Stalin being examples of that). This is one more reason for me not to like artists in politics. I actually think they can do much better for Humanity recalling us what we all have in common, and help us improve individually... they are very well placed to make impact P2P and let networks, incentives etc. spread the word.

<!channel> I've been thinking a lot about NFTs during this fellowship. Yesterday I tried to start thinking about them differently. Specifically, what is the ontology of an NFT. Is it the code? It it its use? What defines this thing? I want to use philosophy to investigate NFTs and see if it can lead to a new understanding of design patterns. If anyone is interested, I'd love to have a virtual coffee / Junto about this and write something.
This is somewhat orthogonal but <@U016C909613> and I now regularly use the word "NFT" in the real world when describing any unique keepsake like a gift or something special someone has given us

I did something similar but with respect to games. For example, a chess piece is defined by its existence in the game but also outside of it. For example, the meaning of a "Rook" is the same in and out of a game but in game you use it with certain procedures. However, interoperability adds to its being in interesting ways. Let's not even bring in blockchain yet. What happens if I use that rook as my piece in monopoly? Is it still a rook? It's in game procedures have definitely changed. But has it changed as a thing? Moving back onto blockchain how does interoperability change the definition of an NFT. Or does it?
Yo I love nfts and would love to talk about them. The idea of uniqueness and ownership and scarcity in a digital setting. It is always what I find myself wanting to build

Really interested to talk about how blockchain could enable a new type of government. 

Similar to this - but not the same. A good example of risks - what are the opportunities?

<https://www.usip.org/publications/2020/07/myanmar-casino-cities-run-blockchain-threaten-nations-sovereignty|https://www.usip.org/publications/2020/07/myanmar-casino-cities-run-blockchain-threaten-nations-sovereignty>

Really interesting <@U016PNPMFSN>. A lot of these technologies / capabilities are developing really rapidly, but we’re thinking hard about how Web3 plays in - programmable incentivization based on sustainability metrics. <@U0169MPEV3R> has a piece in draft about a sustainability-linked UBI - paying people more if they protect their local ecological health. We’re also thinking hard about how to use these contracts as an budgeting mechanism for organizations and governments - a govt sets a target, say to improve air quality. If they fail to meet it, more money is automatically allocated to agencies tasked with making progress …

We’re also starting to look at how smart contracts could underpin next-gen carbon markets, something that is getting <https://www.smithschool.ox.ac.uk/research/sustainable-finance/publications/Business-Green-Next-Gen-Carbon-Markets191017.pdf|a bit of traction> in sustainable finance circles. We think the validation / verification aspect is key - how do we know that offsets work, or that a firm is only emitting as much carbon as they have permits for (see <https://www.ghgsat.com/|GHGSat>)?

Also - way out of left field …. distant future … what about a DAO to own and maintain Earth Observation equipment - satellites and drones … information about the Earth captured and owned by the public … stored on IPFS … available via Ocean protocol … a fully decentralized ecological monitoring system owned by a DAO?

Have replied in a dm to the above. Though the `this environmental surveillance capability allows us to intervene with carrots and sticks to ensure firms behave sustainably` comment reminds me of something Paul Cezanne once said:

"A time is coming when a single carrot, freshly observed, will trigger a revolution"

Really interesting thinkpiece from the Web 3 Spatial folks on the quickest path to decarbonization, using Web 3.

Might be worth a whole junto to discuss — tagging folks who might be interested (cc <@U0174MUAU90> <@U01693HHP9V> <@U017ACMER3P>)

<https://medium.com/@juvenalis/notes-on-machine-governance-c856a85e8a23>
<#C017VAB4WJC|proj-web3-spatial> is here if you wanna jam with them directly — cc <@U016PEM9U5B>

have thought about something that would require something like this to be in existence to really work...something i am calling, air token. basically have oracles verify tree planting and growth to calculate air tokens generated based on size/health/type etc. reward with tokens -- on the other side have govt use cap and trade on carbon, allow emitters to purchase air tokens to cancel out their emissions. combo of satellites/drones could periodically track/verify

lot of awesome uses for crypto -- looking forward to see how web3 spatial protocol progresses!

cc <@U016UNBDY5R> — not sure how much you have gotten to check out the Web 3 Spatial work. might be room for collaboration with Carbonight Network

<https://www.notion.so/gitcoin/Carbonight-Network-443ca4c2197e4a478f5450d647dd32ac>

Great thoughts on types of lonliness — all debilitating in a variety of ways — from Project Horseshoe shared by <@U01733WAA1F>. Important for the KERNEL community and also the variety of folks building for communities to consider: _*how is what we are building helping people build stronger relationships?*_ 

How are we identifying and managing our own loneliness, even before?
